notesStmt.p: Dramatic presentations of the Passion of Christ were a widespread and popular genre of medieval religious theater. Rooted in the tropes of the Easter liturgy (the religious texts and rituals performed during church services at Eastertime), Passion plays and Easter dramas became an established part of devotional culture in Western Europe by the High Middle Ages.

The fifteenth-century Bordesholm Virgin Mary’s Lament translated here is part of this tradition of liturgical drama. It belongs to a popular subgenre of religious plays that focus on the Virgin Mary’s grief during the sacrifice of her son on the Cross. Such plays are probably better understood as devotional aids than as a form of artistic expression equivalent to modern theater. They present Mary as a devotional role model whose perspective on the Passion the audience can adopt and whose sorrow and compassion the audience is prompted to emulate in their own meditations on the sufferings of Christ.

The play starts with a summary of the events of Good Friday given by John the Evangelist, who directly addresses the audience and asks for their devotion and prayer (vv. 1–131). After this introduction, the plot starts with a scene of John meeting Mary and ascending to Calvary, where they find the crucified Christ (vv. 131–196). At the foot of the cross, they are joined by Mary Magdalene and Mary’s sister, the mother of John the Evangelist. Inspired by the account of the crucifixion given in John 19:25 as well as contemporary visual depictions of the crucifixion group, they mourn together and lament the sufferings of Christ (vv. 197–488). After Christ has entrusted Mary to John and uttered his seven last words, he dies hanging on the cross (vv. 488–596). Struck by grief, Mary laments her child’s death, which cuts through her soul in fulfilment of the prophecy of Simeon (Luke 2:25–35). John and the other women join her in grieving (vv. 597–843). A final monologue by John (vv. 844–855) and a communal prayer spoken by the actors together with the audience conclude the play.

As the initial stage directions outline, the Virgin Mary’s Lament is meant to be staged in a church setting as part of the celebrations for Good Friday. Embedded in the liturgy for this feast, the play is framed by hymns sung by the rector, who leads the celebration. The five stage roles (Jesus, Mary, Mary Magdalene, John the Evangelist, the mother of John the Evangelist) are to be played by male members of the clergy equipped with appropriate costumes and stage props.

In addition to stage acting and spoken text, the Virgin Mary’s Lament also includes numerous songs. While many of these musical inserts come from a standardized repertoire of liturgical chant, a few others were specifically written and arranged for this play, sometimes repurposing melodies known from other contemporary contexts. Musical notation for some of these more unusual songs is given in the manuscript and in Kühl’s edition, which served as the basis of our translation. A 1992 recording by the ensemble Sequentia (see Further Reading) gives an impression of how a late medieval staging of this play would have sounded.

This short play, which consists of 855 rhymed vernacular verses as well as some Latin additions, is transmitted in a single manuscript now held by the University Library in Kiel, Germany (Kiel, UB, cod. Bord. mscr. 53). The manuscript was written around 1476 by Johannes Reborch, who was provost of an Augustinian monastery at Bordesholm in Holstein. Reborch likely did not author the play himself but copied or adapted it from an unknown source. While the spoken parts of the play are in a Low German dialect, the accompanying stage directions as well as many of the hymns and chants in the play are in Latin or in a mix of Latin and Low German verses. projectDesc.p: "The Virgin Mary's Lament" is published by The Global Medieval Sourcebook (GMS), a free, open access, and open source compendium of medieval texts in their original languages and in English translation. GMS comprises computer-readable transcriptions or editions alongside new translations of texts dating from the ninth to the sixteenth century and originating in Europe, North Africa, the Middle East, and Asia. The GMS platform includes critical introductions as well as sources for further reading.

editorialDecl.p: Transcriptions and translations are encoded in XML conforming to TEI (P5) guidelines. The original-language text is contained within <lem> tags and translations within <rdg> tags.

interpretation.p: Texts are translated into modern American English with maximum fidelity to the original text, except where it would impair comprehension or good style. Archaisms are preserved where they do not conflict with the aesthetic of the original text. Scribal errors and creative translation choices are marked and discussed in the critical notes.

app.lem: Marienklage
app.rdg: The Virgin Mary's Lament

app.lem: Planctum istum facit beata virgo Maria cum quattor personis deuotis deuotissime bona sexta feria ante prandium in ecclesia ante chorum in loco aliquantaum eleuato vel extra ecclesiam, si bona est aura.
app.rdg: Here begins the most devout lamentation of the Blessed Virgin Mary in a compassionate and devout exposition. Here, the Latin “nota” is not easy to translate. Alternatively, it could be understood to mean “depiction” or “style”. This lamentation is performed faithfully and very devoutly by the Blessed Virgin Mary together with four other characters before lunch on Good Friday, in the church in front of the choir or, if the In medieval monastic contexts, the “prandium” was, according to the Benedictine Rule, the principal meal of the day which the whole community gathered for around noon. light is good, in a moderately raised place outside of the church.

app.lem: Planctus iste non est ludus nec ludibrium, sed est planctus et fletus et pia compassio Marie virginis gloriose.
app.rdg: This lamentation is neither a play nor a funny joke, but is a lamenting and a wailing and devout compassion for the glorious Virgin Mary.

app.lem: Et cuandocunque fit a bonis et deuotis hominibus, in genere siue in specie valde prouocat homines circumstantes ad pium fletum et ad compassionem, sicut facit sermo deuotus bona sexta feria de passione domini nostri Jhesu Cristi.
app.rdg: And in general or in particular, whenever it is performed by good and devout people it will The Latin expression “in genere sive in specie” is a formulaic idiom. Here, it expresses that the described qualities and effects of the play do not only apply to this particular Middle Low German version, but to the genre of Marian lamentations in general. strongly provoke the gathered people to piously cry and feel compassion, just as a devout Good Friday sermon on the passion of our Lord Jesus Christ does.

app.lem: Si non potest fieri bona sexta feria commodose propter sermonem de passione domini, tunc beata virgo faciat istum planctum antea cum suis, sicut feria secunda post dominicam palmarum ante prandium.
app.rdg: If, because of the sermon on the Lord’s passion, it is not possible to perform on Good Friday, at the time when the Blessed Virgin together with her confidantes once broke out into this lamentation, [it shall be performed] on the Monday of the Holy Week before lunch.

app.lem: Iste planctus fit commodose in duabus horis et media.
app.rdg: This lamentation can be conveniently performed in two and a half hours.

app.lem: Et omnia, que tunc fiunt ab illis quinque personis, non debent fieri cum festinacione nec nimia mora, sed medio et bono modo.
app.rdg: And everything which was once done by these five persons shall not be performed in a hurry or exaggeratedly slow, but medium-fast and in a good way.

app.lem: Ille, qui est Jhesus, est deuotus sacerdos.
app.rdg: The actor playing Jesus is a devout priest.

app.lem: Maria iuuenis.
app.rdg: Mary is a young man.

app.lem: Johannes ewangelista sacerdos.
app.rdg: John the Evangelist is a priest.

app.lem: Maria Magdalena et mater Johannes ewangelista iuuenis.
app.rdg: Mary Magdalene and the mother of John are young men.

app.lem: Jhesus debet se preparare cum casula rubra.
app.rdg: Jesus must wear a red vestment.

app.lem: Johannes simili modo.
app.rdg: John must do the same.

app.lem: Jhesus et Johannes debent habere dyademata de papiro; dyadema Jhesu habeat rubram crucem ante et retro.
app.rdg: Jesus and John are wearing crowns made of paper; Jesus’ crown shows a red cross at the front and the back.

app.lem: Maria debet se preparare cum vestibus, sicut Maria Magdalena in nocte pasche.
app.rdg: Mary must wear a garment like that of Mary Magdalene for the Easter vigil.

app.lem: Johannes habeat gladium de ligno cum vagina, quem tenet in manu, quum exit cum rigmo suo.
app.rdg: John has a wooden sword with a sheath which he holds in his hand and with This reference points to a non-extant Easter play that the Augustinian monks of Bordesholm seem to have performed regularly. It shows how late medieval liturgical drama was far from being a singular event and in fact was deeply embedded into the rhythm of monastic life. during his rhymed monologue.

app.lem: Et Johannes debet sepius tangere cor Marie vel pectus eius.
app.rdg: And John has to touch Mary’s heart or Latin “rigmus" is a technical term in medieval drama, denoting a rhymed and spoken (not sung) monologue. chest seven times. And when he has performed his part, he immediately lays down the sword. Gramatically, the Latin „sepius“ makes no sense here. We assume that it is a scribal mistake or an abbreviation for „septimus“, referring to the seven sorrows of the Virgin Mary.

app.lem: Et quum facit actum suum, statim deponit gladium.
app.rdg: And when he has performed his part, he immediately lays down the sword.

app.lem: Iuuenis quidam bene vestitus potest postea lumbos crucifixi.
app.rdg: Well-costumed young men may take away the sword together with the cloth of silk with which the Blessed Virgin before had covered the loins of the Crucified.

app.lem: Dominus Jhesus cum primo exit cum alijs quattuor personis, deuote portat crucem in manibus suis.
app.rdg: In the beginning, the Lord Jesus enters the stage with the four other characters, devoutly carrying the cross in his hands.

app.lem: Et quum cantauit versum "Quoniam tribulacio proxima est", statim deponit crucem.
app.rdg: And when he has sung the verse “For tribulation is near,” he immediately lays down the cross.

app.lem: Et quum faciunt planctum, dominus Jhesus debet habere crucifixum ante se.
app.rdg: And when they perform the lamentation, the Lord Jesus must hold the cross in front of him.

app.lem: Et cuandocunque facit actum, tunc crucem deponit et intrudit crucifixum.
app.rdg: And as soon as he has performed this act, he puts down the cross and rams the crucifix into the ground.

app.lem: Beata virgo stat a dextris Jhesu Cristi cum Maria Magdalena.
app.rdg: Together with Mary Magdalene, the Blessed Virgin stands on the right side of Jesus.

app.lem: Johannes a sinistris cum matre sua.
app.rdg: John and his mother stand on the left.

app.lem: Virgo Maria quum facit actum suum, vadit ad medium et aliquando vertit se ad filium ad orientum, aliquando ad occidentem, aliquando ad aquilones, aliquando ad meridiem cum gladio Symeonis, quem tenet beatus Johannes ante pectus eius.
app.rdg: When the Virgin Mary performs her part, she steps into the center and at one point turns east towards her son, at one point to the west, at another point to the north, and at one point to the south and towards the sword of Simeon, which St. John holds to her chest.

app.lem: Aliquando beata virgo expandit brachia sua, aliquando leuat manus suas ad filium cum oculis: omnia cum moderamine.
app.rdg: At one point, the Blessed Virgin reaches out her arms, Medieval churches are generally oriented to the east: Therefore, the altar, cross and choir are behind Mary (east), the nave with the audience is in front of her (west), John the Evangelist stands to her left (south) and north means right of her. at another point she raises her hands and eyes to her son: all with moderation.

app.lem: Quandocunque fecit actum suum, vadit at locum suum et stat a dextris.
app.rdg: As soon as she has performed her part, she steps back to her place and stands on the right.

app.lem: Simili modo faciunt alij.
app.rdg: The others do the same.

app.lem: Quum exeunt et quum intrant, faciunt tria paria: primo exit dominus Jhesus cum cruce cum Johanne ewangelista, post hos beata virgo cum Maria Magdalena, vltimo mater Johannes cum rectore, et ille incipit psalmum "Circumdederunt me viri mendaces" vsque ad locum preparatum.
app.rdg: When they enter and exit the stage, they make up three pairs: first of all, the Lord Jesus Here, the use of Latin words is counterintuitive to English speakers: „exire“ means entering, „intrare“ exiting the stage. enters with the cross and John the Evangelist, after them the Blessed Virgin and Mary Magdalene, finally the mother of John with the rector, who strikes up the psalm “Lying men surrounded me” The rector is the priest who leads the liturgical singing and recitations that take place during the play. until [he reaches] a prepared place.

app.lem: Ffinito psalmo dominus Jhesus cantat solus versum "Quoniam tribulacio proxima est" et vertit faciem ad occidentem semper.
app.rdg: After the end of the psalm, Jesus alone sings the verse “For tribulation is near,” turns his face westwards and stays this way.

app.lem: Vnusquisque dicat rigmum suum cum deuocione plangendo in eadem et nota et dono discreto.
app.rdg: Everyone recites his rhymed Jesus is facing the audience. monologue mourning with devotion, in the same character and in a discreet tone of voice. Here, the sonorization typical for Middle Low German is reflected in the Latin spelling of the manuscript: „dono“ does not derive from „donum“ (meaning „gift“), but from „tonus“ (meaning „tone of voice,“ „note,“ „inflection“).

app.lem: Quum Jhesus finiuit versum "Quoniam tribulacio", Johannes ewangelista statim dicit ad omnem populum plangendo:
app.rdg: When Jesus has finished the verse “For tribulation is near,” John the Evangelist immediately turns to all the people and sorrowfully says:

app.rdg: John the Evangelist:

app.lem: Horet, gij salighen lude,
app.rdg: Listen, you blessed people,

app.lem: Vnde latet juw beduden,
app.rdg: and let it be shown to you

app.lem: Huden vmme vnsen wyllen heft geleden de marter grot,

app.lem: Dar tho ok den bytteren dot!
app.rdg: and, in addition to that, bitter death!

app.lem: Horet ersten, wo vnse leue here an der tijt to completen
app.rdg: Hear, first of all, how our dear Lord at the time of Compline

app.lem: Vmme vnsen wyllen blodich sweet wolde sweten;

app.lem: Dat he alwyllynges ok wolde ga&esup;n,

app.rdg: and how he kissed Judas, his disloyal friend,

app.lem: Kussen wolde vor syne munt
app.rdg: on the mouth,

app.lem: Vnde valsklyken wolde vorraden werden,
app.rdg: when he was about to be betrayed as treacherously

app.rdg: as any man who ever walked the earth.

app.rdg: took him captive as if he were a murderer or a thief.

app.rdg: he was also dragged before Annas and bound;

app.rdg: he [Annas] began to question him about his teachings

app.rdg: There he was struck on his holy cheeks.

app.lem: Horet, wo vnse leue here in der nachtstunde
app.rdg: Hear how our dear Lord on that night

app.lem: Vmme vnsen wyllen wart gevangen vnde gebunden
app.rdg: was taken captive and bound for our sake

app.lem: Vnde wort vor byschop Cayphas getoghen!
app.rdg: and was dragged before bishop Cayphas!

app.rdg: there about how they might put him to death.

app.rdg: There our dear Lord heard many scornful words:

app.rdg: they insulted his worthy, holy birth,

app.lem: Also deger weren se vorblynd.
app.rdg: that is how very blind they were.

app.rdg: They bound his godly eyes;

app.rdg: all around him stood the grim Jews

app.rdg: who took him for a fool

app.rdg: and struck him around his godly ears.

app.rdg: They spoke mockingly: if you are Christ

app.rdg: O dear friends, what a terrible offence this was to him!

app.lem: Dar wart he so rechte ouele bedacht:
app.rdg: There he was truly mistreated:

app.lem: Se seden, dat vnse here were eyn droghenere
app.rdg: they said that our Lord was a deceiver

app.lem: Vnde lerede deme volke ok valsche lere.
app.rdg: and also that he taught the people false teachings.

app.lem: Pylatus sende vnsen heren hen to herodes;
app.rdg: Pilot sent our Lord to Herod

app.lem: De wart sere gevrowet des:
app.rdg: who was very pleased about this:

app.lem: He me&esup;nde, dat he were eyn to&esup;uerer
app.rdg: he thought that he [our Lord] was a conjurer

app.lem: Vnde ok der lude gokeler.
app.rdg: and also a misleader of the people.

app.lem: Herodes hadde gerne wunder van em geseen;
app.rdg: Herod would have gladly seen some of his miracles;

app.lem: Des enmochte em doch nicht bescheen.
app.rdg: but that was not to happen for him.

app.lem: He began vnsen heren vele to vraghen,
app.rdg: He began to ask our Lord many questions

app.lem: Vnde de yoden begunden ouer em sere to klaghen:
app.rdg: and the Jews began to complain greatly about him;

app.lem: Vnse here sweech al stylle vnde wolde em nicht berichten,
app.rdg: and our Lord kept completely silent and would not tell him anything;

app.lem: Do bespottede Herodes Jhesum Cristum myt alle synen knechten,
app.rdg: then Herod, with all his men, mocked Jesus Christ.

app.lem: He to&esup;ch em eyn do&esup;ren kleyt an
app.rdg: He dressed him in a fool’s costume

app.lem: Dat le&esup;et vnse leue here myt groder dult
app.rdg: Our dear Lord endured this with great patience

app.rdg: He forgave one of them in his final hour

app.lem: Dar negest eschede vnse leue here drynken;
app.rdg: Thereafter our beloved Lord asked for a drink;

app.lem: Do leten se em etyk vnde gallen schenken.
app.rdg: then they had vinegar and gall brought to him.

app.lem: Dar neghest sprak he: consummatum est!
app.rdg: Thereafter he spoke: “it is finished!" “consummatum est”, John 19:30

app.lem: Vnde ok: in dyne hende bevole ik, vader, mynen geyst!
app.rdg: And also: “In your hands father, I command my spirit!”

app.lem: Also leyt do den bytteren dot vnse leue here.
app.rdg: Thus our lord suffered bitter death.

app.lem: Ok wart syne hilghe syde doresteken myt enem spere;
app.rdg: Thus his holy side was pierced with a lance;

app.lem: Dar vlo&esup;t vth water vnde blot.
app.rdg: water and blood flowed out of it.

app.lem: Dar sach me do an den creaturen yammer grot:
app.rdg: Then the creatures were seen to suffer great sorrow:

app.lem: De harden steyne toreten van synen pynen,
app.rdg: The hard stones shattered for his pain,

app.lem: Der sune let van groter dro&esup;fnisse ere schynent,
app.rdg: The sun stopped shining for great distress,

app.lem: De erde began van grotem yammer to beuen,
app.rdg: The earth began to quake for great sorrow,

app.lem: De doden in den grauen begunden ok wedder to leuen. -
app.rdg: The dead in the graves came back to life again.

app.lem: Leue vrunde, gy hebben hort, wat leden het Jhesus Cristus vnse
app.rdg: Dear friends, you have heard what our dear Lord Jesus Christ has suffered.

app.lem: Nu wyl ik juw lesen noch vuste mere:
app.rdg: Now I want to read much more to you:

app.lem: Dat lydent sunte Marien, dat wyl wij hijr nu anheuen.
app.rdg: We now want to start telling what St. Mary suffered.

app.lem: God late juw so lange leuen,
app.rdg: May God let you live so long

app.lem: Dat dij syne hulde vordenen, -
app.rdg: that you earn his grace,

app.lem: Vnde helpet huden sunte Marien wenen!
app.rdg: and, today, help to mourn St. Mary!

app.lem: Betrachtet huten myt vlyte ere byttercheyt,
app.rdg: Consider carefully today her bitterness

app.lem: De se so swarlyken leyt
app.rdg: that she suffered so deeply

app.lem: Vmme eres leuen kyndes dot,
app.rdg: for the death of her beloved child,

app.lem: Dar he vns mede geloset heft vth aller not!
app.rdg: by which he delivered us from all our misery!

app.lem: Hijr vmme, gij vrowen vnde ok gij man,
app.rdg: For that reason, all you women and men,

app.lem: Latet juw ere lydent to herten ga&esup;n!
app.rdg: let her suffering enter your heart!

app.lem: Bewenet dat van herten ynnichliken,
app.rdg: Lament this profoundly from the heart,

app.lem: Dat gij mogen myt vrowden ewychlyken
app.rdg: so that you can be joyfully and eternally

app.lem: Myt gode vnde myt Marien wesen
app.rdg: with God and with Mary

app.lem: Vnde vor der ewygen helle genesen!
app.rdg: and be saved from eternal Hell!

app.lem: Dat vns dat allen beschee,
app.rdg: For this, which is happening to all of us,

app.lem: So gat sytten vp juwe knee,
app.rdg: go down on your knees,

app.lem: Spreket eyn Pater noster myt ynnicheyt
app.rdg: say a heart-felt pater noster

app.lem: Vnde ok Aue Maria to juwer selen salycheyt!
app.rdg: and an Ave Maria for the salvation of your soul!

app.lem: Johannes post Pater noster dicit ad omnem populum
app.rdg: Following the paternoster, John says to all of the people:

app.lem: Ghat sytten, gy leuen kynder, an dessen guden daghe,
app.rdg: Be seated, dear children on this fine day,

app.lem: Horet der reynen junckfrowen Marien weynent vnde klaghe!
app.rdg: hear the weeping and lament of the pure virgin Mary!

app.lem: Beata virgo Maria iucipit hic planctum suum dolorosissimum deuotissime. Psalmus:
app.rdg: St. Virgin Mary here piously begins her most sorrowful lamentation. Psalm:

app.lem: *Anxiatus est in me spiritus meus,
app.rdg: *My spirit is afraid,

app.lem: *In me turbatum est cor meum!
app.rdg: *My heart is restless!

app.lem: *Nu bedrouet sik myn geyst an mynem herten sere,
app.rdg: *Now the spirit in my heart becomes very sad,

app.lem: *Noch mer wen gy wyf gewan dorch mynes kyndes ere.
app.rdg: *exceeding even what you, women, gained through my child’s honor.

app.lem: Sancta Maria dicit et vertit se ad populum
app.rdg: St. Mary speaks and turns toward the audience.

app.lem: O aller barmhertigeste god,
app.rdg: Oh most merciful God,

app.lem: Wo grot ys myne klaghe vnde myn not
app.rdg: how great is my lament and my suffering

app.lem: Vmme Jhesus Cristum, den leuen sone myn!
app.rdg: because of Jesus Christ, my beloved son!

app.lem: Ik vruchte, he mot in groten noden syn.
app.rdg: I fear he may be in great peril.

app.lem: Ach woste yk, wor yk mochte
app.rdg: Alas, if I only knew where I could

app.lem: Ghan, dar yk ene sochte!
app.rdg: go to search for him!

app.lem: Dar gynge yk myt wyllen gerne hyn,
app.rdg: Gladly and willingly I’d go there

app.lem: Scholdet ok kosten dat leuent myn.
app.rdg: even if it would cost my life.

app.lem: Beata virgo cautat hoc
app.rdg: The blessed virgin sings this:

app.lem: Conturbata sunt omnia ossa mea, et anima mea turbata est valde.
app.rdg: All my bones are disquieted, and my soul is in great turmoil.

app.lem: Sancta Maria statim dicit ad Johannem:
app.rdg: St. Mary immediately says to John:

app.lem: Johannes, myn leue o&esup;m, wat mach dat beduden?
app.rdg: John, my dear nephew, what may that mean?

app.lem: Ghynnert synt gesammelt vele lude,
app.rdg: Many people have gathered,

app.lem: Se ropen lude und beren swar.
app.rdg: they are grieving loudly and behaving sadly.

app.lem: Eya nu gha myt my alda&esup;r
app.rdg: Come on, go there with me,

app.lem: La&esup;t vns beseen, wat see bedryuen!
app.rdg: let us have a look at what they are doing!

app.lem: Sanctus Johannes respondet
app.rdg: St. John responds:

app.lem: Neen, Maria leue medder wij moget leuer blyuen!
app.rdg: No, dear mother Mary, we would rather stay here!

app.lem: De yoden synt eres ouermodes also vil,
app.rdg: The Jews are so full of arrogance,

app.lem: Vor war ik dy dat saghen wyl.
app.rdg: in truth I want to tell you this!

app.lem: Se brochten sunte Peter darto in desser nacht,
app.rdg: They made St. Peter this night,

app.lem: Dat he synes heren vorso&esup;k vnde syner macht;
app.rdg: forsake his lord and his power;

app.lem: Schege my armen manne ok also,
app.rdg: if the same thing happened to me, a mere man,

app.lem: Des worde yk nummer vro.
app.rdg: I would never be happy again.

app.lem: Sancta Maria respondit
app.rdg: St. Mary responds:

app.lem: Johannes, myn vil leue vrund,
app.rdg: John, my very dear friend,

app.lem: Twyde my an desser stund,
app.rdg: listen to me at this hour

app.lem: Vnde ga myt my aldar,
app.rdg: and go with me there,

app.lem: Wente yd ys dar mennich var!
app.rdg: because there are many dangers!

app.lem: Lat vns beseen, wat se bedryuen!
app.rdg: Let us see what they are doing!

app.lem: Ik wyl stede by dy blyuen;
app.rdg: I will remain ever by your side;

app.lem: Myt der warheyt schaltu dat beseen:
app.rdg: in truth, you shall see this:

app.lem: Ik wyl vaste sta&esup;n vnde ok nicht van dy vleen
app.rdg: I will remain steadfast and not leave your side.

app.lem: Sume nicht! wij mogen nu nicht lenger stan.
app.rdg: Don’t delay! Let’s not stay here any longer.

app.lem: Sanctus Johannes respondet
app.rdg: St. John responds:

app.lem: Maria, leue medder, yk wyl gerne myt dy ga&esup;n.
app.rdg: Mary, dear mother, I will gladly go with you.

app.lem: Scholde yk ok darvmme lyn den bytteren dot,
app.rdg: Even if I suffer a bitter death,

app.lem: Ik vorlate dy nicht in desser groten not.
app.rdg: I will not abandon you in this great peril.

app.lem: Valde modicum transeunt, silicet, si est opus, usque ad medium circuli. Et sancta Maria statim incipit cantare
app.rdg: Quickly they move over, if necessary; namely, up into middle of the circle. And St. Mary immediately begins to sing:

app.lem: *Owe des ghandes, des yk gha
app.rdg: *Alas that I walk

app.lem: *Myt yamer vnde myt ruwen!
app.rdg: *With pain and sorrow!

app.lem: *Myn kynt an deme crutze steyt,
app.rdg: *My child is standing with the cross,

app.lem: *Myn leyt wil sik vornuwen.
app.rdg: *My suffering begins again.

app.lem: (Hic imponit gladium)
app.rdg: (Here she picks up the sword)

app.lem: *Owe, owy, owe
app.rdg: *Alas, alas, alas

app.lem: *Des gandes, des yk nu ghe!
app.rdg: *That I must walk this path!

app.lem: *Ik mot scrygen yummermer:
app.rdg: *I must wail now and forever:

app.lem: *Owe, owy, owe!
app.rdg: *Alas, alas, alas!

app.lem: *Bedrouet synt de synne myn,
app.rdg: *My senses are defeated,

app.lem: *Went de heylant ys in pyn,
app.rdg: *because the Saviour is in pain

app.lem: *De myn kynt ys vnde ok myn god
app.rdg: *who is my child and also my God,

app.lem: *Vnde der enghel sabaoth.
app.rdg: *and the lord of angels. According to Lexer, “sabaoth” means king of kings.

app.lem: *Owy, owe!
app.rdg: *Alas, alas!

app.lem: *Owe, leyder wat ik nu vynde
app.rdg: *Alas, more painful still is what I see

app.lem: *An mynem herten truwen kynde!
app.rdg: *in the child dear to my heart!

app.lem: (Hic deponit gladium)
app.rdg: (Here she puts down the sword.)

app.lem: *Wor schal ik arme maget blyuen?
app.rdg: *Where shall I, poor maiden remain?

app.lem: *Dot, kum her vnde my vorswynde!
app.rdg: *Death, come here and claim me!

app.lem: Sancta Maria extendit manum ad filium hic et dicit ad sanctum Johannes
app.rdg: Here St. Mary extends her hand to her son and says to St. John:

app.lem: See, Johannes leue o&esup;m,
app.rdg: See, John, dear nephew,

app.lem: Wat ys gehanget vor vns an den bo&esup;m,
app.rdg: what is hanging before us on the tree,

app.lem: Ys yd eyn mynsche edder eyn worm?
app.rdg: is it a man or a serpent?

app.lem: Id wyndet sik in den neghelen vnde drift groten storm;
app.rdg: It twists itself on the nails and is in the great throes of death;

app.lem: Id mot in groten bytteren pynen syn.
app.rdg: it must be in great and bitter pain.

app.lem: Sanctus Johannes respondet plangendo
app.rdg: St. John responds, mourning:

app.lem: Owe, Maria, dat ys dat leue kynt dyn!
app.rdg: Alas Mary, that is your beloved child!

app.lem: See, wo yd gevyllet sta&esup;t
app.rdg: See, how he hangs there tormented

app.lem: Vnde ok vp synem hilgen houede ha&esup;t
app.rdg: and around his holy head

app.lem: Van scharpen do&esup;rne eyne krone!
app.rdg: he has a crown of sharp thorns!

app.lem: Dat hilge blot vlut ouer syn antlat schone,
app.rdg: Holy blood flows over his lovely face

app.lem: Ok ouer syne ogen bet in syne munt.
app.rdg: Tand over his eyes and into his mouth.

app.lem: O Maria, see, wo yd steyt gewund:
app.rdg: O Mary, see how he hangs there tortured:

app.lem: Dat mochte eynem stene entfarmen!
app.rdg: that even a stone could be moved by it!

app.lem: O leuen kyndere, helpet dat altomale bekarmen!
app.rdg: O dear children, now all help to lament him!

app.lem: Sancta Maria respondet:
app.rdg: Saint Mary responds:

app.lem: Owe, ys dat myn leue truten sone?
app.rdg: Alas, is that my dear beloved son?

app.lem: Ik wolde, dat syne scharpen dornekrone
app.rdg: I wish that his sharp crown of thorns

app.lem: Vp mynem houede sete an dessen stunden,
app.rdg: sat on my head in this hour,

app.lem: Vnde syne mennichualdigen depen wunden
app.rdg: and his many deep wounds

app.lem: Vor em weren an mynem lyue,
app.rdg: were on my body

app.lem: Vppe dat he mochte leuendich blyuen.
app.rdg: instead of his so that he could stay alive.

app.lem: Et cantat:
app.rdg: And she sings:

app.lem: *Owe, yamer vnde not!
app.rdg: *Alas, pain and misery!

app.lem: *Owe, mynes leuen kyndes dot,
app.rdg: *Alas, the death of my dear child

app.lem: *Den ik an herten drage
app.rdg: *that I carry in my heart

app.lem: *Vnde so yamerliken klaghe!
app.rdg: *and lament so sorrowfully!

app.lem: *Yo gha ik wedder vnde dort,
app.rdg: *Now I go here and there,

app.lem: *Noch entret hijr nemant vort,
app.rdg: *and still no one here steps forward

app.lem: *De desse martere beweynede!
app.rdg: *to mourn this suffering!

app.lem: *Owe, elende!
app.rdg: *Alas, miserable ones!

app.lem: (Hic plangit cum manibus.)
app.rdg: (Now she gestures mournfully with her hands.)

app.lem: *Owy, owe my huten vnde jummermer
app.rdg: Alas, woe is me today and forevermore

app.lem: *Vmme mynes kyndes do&esup;t!
app.rdg: *because of my child’s death!

app.lem: *Myn kummer ys so rechte grot.
app.rdg: *My sorrow is so very great.

app.lem: *Owy, owe!
app.rdg: *Alas, woe is me!

app.lem: Et dicit vlterius
app.rdg: And continues:

app.lem: Eya, moderlyke herte,
app.rdg: Oh, motherly heart,

app.lem: Wat lydestu pyne vnde smerte!
app.rdg: how you are suffering misery and pain!

app.lem: Dominus Jhesus dicit habens crucifixum ante se
app.rdg: Holding the cross in front of him, Lord Jesus says:

app.lem: Myn volk, wo seer hestu dy an my gewraken!
app.rdg: My people, how much you have tormented me!

app.lem: Ik hebbe dy doch nicht to leyde gedan edder gespraken?
app.rdg: I didn’t do or say anything to harm you.

app.lem: Myn volk, yk vorede dy ouer dat wylde meer
app.rdg: My people, I lead you over the wild sea

app.lem: Vnde vordruckede Pharaonis heer;
app.rdg: and I swallowed Faroah’s army;

app.lem: Ik reghende dy enghelsch brod
app.rdg: I made the angels’ bread rain down

app.lem: Yn der wo&esup;stenyge to dyner no&esup;t:
app.rdg: in the desert to relieve your hardship:

app.lem: Darvmme hestu my ghevanghen
app.rdg: this is why you captured me

app.lem: Vnde darto an dat crutze gehanghen!
app.rdg: and hung me on the cross!

app.lem: De vosse hebben ere kulen,
app.rdg: Foxes have their dens

app.lem: Dar se ynne schulen,
app.rdg: where they hide,

app.lem: De vogele hebben ere neste,
app.rdg: birds have their nests,

app.lem: De heren hebben ere gheveste, -
app.rdg: lords have their strongholds,

app.lem: Des mynschen sone leyder nicht enha&esup;t,
app.rdg: -- the son of man sadly doesn’t have any place

app.lem: Dar syn kranke houet ane sta&esup;t.
app.rdg: where his poor head may rest.

app.lem: Owy vnde we, wart doch ny mynschen so we!
app.rdg: Alas and alas, never did anyone suffer so much!

app.lem: Sancta Maria cantat post hoc
app.rdg: Then St. Mary sings:

app.lem: *Ik horede enen ro&esup;p:
app.rdg: *I heard a cry:

app.lem: *Dat ys mynt kynt Jhesus, de myr geschop
app.rdg: *that is my child Jesus, who created me

app.lem: *Vnde al de werlt gemeyne;
app.rdg: *and all the world together;

app.lem: *Des mot yk arme schrygen vnde weynen.
app.rdg: *because of that I must weep and cry.

app.lem: *Van Jherusalem gy vrowen,
app.rdg: *You women of Jerusalem,

app.lem: *Nu helpet huden schowen
app.rdg: *now join me in watching

app.lem: *Mynes leuen kyndes dot,
app.rdg: *the death of my beloved child,

app.lem: *Dat hyr hanget naket vnde blot!
app.rdg: *who hangs here naked and stripped.

app.lem: *Owy, owe!
app.rdg: *Alas, alas!

app.lem: Sancta Maria dicit post hoc ricmum
app.rdg: After these rhymes, St. Mary says:

app.lem: Ach wo grote pyne vnde smerte
app.rdg: Oh, what great pain and sorrow

app.lem: Lydet myn arm bedrouede herte
app.rdg: my poor afflicted heart suffers

app.lem: Vmme mynes leuen kyndes byttercheyt,
app.rdg: Because of the torment of my dear child,

app.lem: Dat in so groter not an deme hilgen crutze steyt!
app.rdg: who hangs on the holt cross in such great misery!

app.lem: Weren vnse herte ok van steynen,
app.rdg: Even if our hearts were of stone,

app.lem: Se mosten doch nu mede weynen.
app.rdg: They would still have to weep with us.

app.lem: Sancta Maria vertit se ad filias Jerusalem dicens vel cantans
app.rdg: St. Mary turns to the daughters of Jerusalem, saying, or rather singing:

app.lem: *Weynet gij truwen susteren myn,
app.rdg: *Weep you loyal sisters of mine,

app.lem: *Helpet my armen drouych syn
app.rdg: *join me in my sadness

app.lem: *Vnde klagen mynen not!
app.rdg: *and lament my misery!

app.lem: *Myn kummer ys worden grot
app.rdg: *My grief has grown and grown

app.lem: *Vmme mynes kyndes do&esup;t.
app.rdg: *at the death of my child.

app.lem: Et dicit vltra ad filias Jherusalem
app.rdg: And she says, continuing, to the daughters of Jerusalem:

app.lem: Gij leuen sustere, latet juw entbarmen
app.rdg: You dear sisters,

app.lem: Huden ouer my vyl armen!
app.rdg: have pity today for poor me!

app.lem: Seet an myne smerte vnde grote byttercheyt,
app.rdg: Look at my pain and my great torment,

app.lem: De yk an mynem herten drage vmme mynes kyndes leyt!
app.rdg: that I carry in my heart because of my child’s suffering!

app.lem: Sancta Maria Magdalena
app.rdg: St. Mary Magdalene:

app.lem: *O quantus luctus
app.rdg: *Oh, what great grief

app.lem: *Nobis est inductus
app.rdg: *is laid upon us

app.lem: *Pre hac tristicia!
app.rdg: *by this sadness!

app.lem: *Owe vns armen!
app.rdg: *Alas, poor us!

app.lem: *Got late sik irbarmen
app.rdg: *God have mercy

app.lem: *Ouer vnse grote leyt!
app.rdg: *on our suffering!

app.lem: Sancta Maria Magdalena vadit ad medium et dicit ricmum
app.rdg: St. Mary Magdalene goes to the center and says in rhyme:

app.lem: Owe, wo grote yamercheyt
app.rdg: Alas, how great sorrow

app.lem: Vns armen vrowen nu besteyt
app.rdg: affects us poor women now

app.lem: Dorch de bytteren martere vnses leuen heren,
app.rdg: because of the bitter martyrdom of our dear Lord,

app.lem: Den huten de yoden myt groten vneren
app.rdg: whom today the Jews, with great dishonor,

app.lem: Vnde myt vnschult hebben to deme dode bracht!
app.rdg: put to death, an innocent man!

app.lem: Eya, dyt ys wol eyn bedrouet dach,
app.rdg: Oh, this is indeed a sorrowful day,

app.lem: Dat wij ene vor vns hanghen seen!
app.rdg: on which we see him hanging before us!

app.lem: Wo mochte vns groter leyt bescheen!
app.rdg: How could any greater sorrow befall us!

app.lem: O leue here Jhesu Criste, wo gherne stoure yk vmme dy,
app.rdg: O, beloved lord Jesus Christ, how gladly I would die in your place,

app.lem: Wente van groten sunden hestu gheloset my.
app.rdg: because you have delivered me from great sins.

app.lem: Et cantat vlterius pro gratiarum actione
app.rdg: And she continues in song, as an act of gratitude:

app.lem: *Ghelauet systu, here Jhesu Crist,
app.rdg: *Praise be unto you, lord Jesus Christ

app.lem: *Went du also barmehertich byst,
app.rdg: *because you are so merciful,

app.lem: *Dattu dy yo wult irbarmen
app.rdg: *that you show mercy

app.lem: *Ouer my vyl armen!
app.rdg: *to poor me!

app.lem: *Du hest geloset my,
app.rdg: *you have saved me;

app.lem: *Des wyl yk jummer lauen dy.
app.rdg: *for that I will always praise you.

app.lem: Maria Magdalena dicit statim ad beatam virginem
app.rdg: Mary Magdalene immediately says to the Blessed Virgin:

app.lem: O Maria, eddele, reyne maghet,
app.rdg: Oh Mary, noble and pure maiden,

app.lem: Dyn grote lydent sij deme leuen gode gheklaghet.
app.rdg: your great suffering shall be mourned before God.

app.lem: Mater Johannis ewangeliste cantat post hoc
app.rdg: Then the mother of John the Evangelist sings:

app.lem: *Jam auctor lucis
app.rdg: *Now the creator of light

app.lem: *Nunc in ligno crucis
app.rdg: *hangs constrained

app.lem: *Stat in angustia.
app.rdg: *on the wood of a cross.

app.lem: *Nu sy wij myt sorgen
app.rdg: *Now, today, we are

app.lem: *Huten gar vorborgen
app.rdg: *laden with troubles

app.lem: *Vnde in der yamercheyt.
app.rdg: *and in sorrow.

app.lem: Mater Johannis dicit
app.rdg: The mother of John says:

app.lem: O wo grote not vnde smerte
app.rdg: Oh what great misery and pain

app.lem: Lyden nu vnse bedroueden herte,
app.rdg: our saddened hearts suffer now

app.lem: Wente wij Jhesum Cristum, der waren sunnen schyn,
app.rdg: because we see Jesus Christ, the true light of the sun,

app.lem: In groter yamercheyt vor vns hangen seen!
app.rdg: hanging in front of us in great sorrow!

app.lem: O leuen kyndere, bewenet nu vnses heren dot,
app.rdg: Oh dear children, now weep for our lord’s death

app.lem: Vppe dat he vns mote losen vth aller no&esup;t!
app.rdg: so that he might deliver us from all hardship!

app.lem: O leue here Jhesu Criste, mochte yk nu myt dy steruen
app.rdg: O dear lord Jesus Christ, if I could die with you now,

app.lem: Vnde also dyne hulde vorweruen,
app.rdg: and with that procure your grace,

app.lem: Ik sumede nicht bet tho morghen
app.rdg: I would not wait until tomorrow

app.lem: Vnde wolde dar ok nicht vore sorghen.
app.rdg: and also would not think twice about it.

app.lem: Maria, leue suster, dyn grote lydent vnde weynen
app.rdg: Mary, dear sister, your great suffering and weeping

app.lem: Mochte vntfarmen deme harden steyne.
app.rdg: would move a hard stone to pity.

app.lem: Sancta Maria vertit se ad populum et dicit
app.rdg: St. Mary turns to the audience and says:

app.lem: Ach wo grote pyne vnde smerte
app.rdg: Oh, what great pain and sorrow

app.lem: Lydet myn arme bedrouede herte
app.rdg: my poor afflicted heart suffers

app.lem: Vmme mynes leuen kyndes byttercheyt,
app.rdg: Because of the torment of my dear child,

app.lem: De in so groter not an deme hilgen crutze steyt!
app.rdg: ho hangs on the holy cross in such great misery!

app.lem: Weren vnse herte ok van steynen,
app.rdg: Even if our hearts were of stone,

app.lem: See mosten doch nu mede weynen.
app.rdg: they would still have to weep with us.

app.lem: Maria cantat
app.rdg: Mary sings:

app.lem: Vrunt Johannes, neue gute,
app.rdg: Friend John, dear nephew,

app.lem: Help my armen godes moter
app.rdg: help me, poor mother of God

app.lem: Klagen mynes kyndes leuent,
app.rdg: to lament the life of my child

app.lem: Dat deme dode ys gegeuen!
app.rdg: who has been put to death!

app.lem: O wat Cristus duldet
app.rdg: Oh what Christ suffers,

app.lem: Vnde an deme crutze sweuet
app.rdg: hanging on the cross,

app.lem: Gar al vnuorschuldt!
app.rdg: free of guilt!

app.lem: Sancta Maria ad filium suum benedictum dicit hoc et ad sanctum Johannem ewangelistam
app.rdg: St. Mary says this to her blessed son and to St. John the Evangelist:

app.lem: O wy vnde we, wo grot herteleyt
app.rdg: Oh, alas and alack, what great heartache

app.lem: Ys my armen bedroueden moder nu bereyt,
app.rdg: now afflicts me, a poor wretched mother,

app.lem: O leue kynt, vmme de bytteren marter dyn!
app.rdg: O dear child, because of your bitter torment!

app.lem: Hijr vmme, Johannes, leue neue myn,
app.rdg: Therefore John, my dear nephew,

app.lem: Help my armen moder beklagen vnde beweynen
app.rdg: help this poor mother to lament and bewail

app.lem: Jhesum Cristum den vyl reynen,
app.rdg: Jesus Christ, in his purity

app.lem: Den de yoden hebben gevanghen
app.rdg: whom the Jews took captive

app.lem: Vnde ok an dat hilge crutze ghehangen!
app.rdg: and hanged on that holy cross!

app.lem: Leue o&esup;m, lat dy dit to herten ga&esup;n,
app.rdg: Dear nephew, let this enter your heart,

app.lem: Wente he dy alle gud heft geda&esup;n!
app.rdg: Tbecause he has only done good things for you!

app.lem: Sanctus Johannes cantat et vertit se ad populum
app.rdg: Saint John sings and turns to the people:

app.lem: Tristor et cuncti tristantur
app.rdg: I am saddened and all are saddened

app.lem: De tua tristicia;
app.rdg: because of your misery;

app.lem: [Omnes] Tecum lacrimantur,
app.rdg: all are crying with you,

app.lem: Eructant suspiria.
app.rdg: they are breaking out in loud sighs.

app.lem: Hic rubescit oculus,
app.rdg: These eyes are becoming red,

app.lem: Flet fidelis populus
app.rdg: the faithful people cry

app.lem: De Cristi mesticia.
app.rdg: over Christ’s torments.

app.lem: Maria, moder vnde maget reyne,
app.rdg: Mary, mother and pure virgin,

app.lem: Yk byn dyner suster kynt.
app.rdg: I am your sister’s child.

app.lem: Dyn grote scrygent vnde dyn weynent
app.rdg: Your great crying and wailing

app.lem: Klagen alle, de hijr synt.
app.rdg: is lamented by all who are present.

app.lem: Hijr wert vyl mennich oge rot
app.rdg: Here many eyes are turning red

app.lem: Vmme dynes kyndes dot,
app.rdg: because of the death of your child

app.lem: Dat hijr hanget ver vns blot.
app.rdg: who hangs here in front of us naked.

app.lem: Johannes vltra dicit ad Mariam, matrem Cristi
app.rdg: John then says to Mary, mother of Christ:

app.lem: Maria, leue medder, he scholde eyn steynen herte dragen,
app.rdg: Mary, dear mother, he would have to have a heart of stone,

app.lem: De dynes kyndes dot nicht kunde helpen beklagen;
app.rdg: who could refrain from helping lament the death of your child.

app.lem: Wart gy mynsche so steynen,
app.rdg: Are you people made of stone

app.lem: De nu myt vns nicht kunde weynen?
app.rdg: that you cannot cry with us?

app.lem: Maria, leue medder, we nu wyl rechte ouerdencken
app.rdg: Mary, dear mother, the one who will now rightly consider

app.lem: Vnde ok in syn herte sencken
app.rdg: and take into his heart your crying,

app.lem: Dyn weynent, den scrygent, dynes reynen herten not
app.rdg: Tyour wailing, the grief of your pure heart

app.lem: Vnde dynes leuen kyndes bytter dot,
app.rdg: and the bitter death of your dead child,

app.lem: De mot myt dy trurent han
app.rdg: can share your sorrow

app.lem: Vnde aller werlde valsche vrowde la&esup;n.
app.rdg: and relinquish the false joy of all the world.

app.lem: Sancta Maria Magdalena et mater Johannis ewangeliste simul cantat
app.rdg: St. Mary Magdalene and the mother of John the Evangelist sing together:

app.lem: O quam tristis et afflicta
app.rdg: Oh, how sad and afflicted

app.lem: Fuit illa benedicta
app.rdg: was the blessed

app.lem: Mater vnigeniti!
app.rdg: mother of the incarnated!

app.lem: Quis est homo, qui non fleret,
app.rdg: Who is the man who does not cry,

app.lem: Matrem Cristi si videret
app.rdg: when he sees the mother of Christ

app.lem: In tanto supplicio?
app.rdg: in such great anguish?

app.lem: Mater Johannis dicit ricmum
app.rdg: The mother of John says in rhyme:

app.lem: Ach, ach, wo sere lyde wy grote swere
app.rdg: Alas, alas, how greatly we bear an immense burden

app.lem: Vmme dy, o leue truten here!
app.rdg: for your sake, oh dear beloved lord!

app.lem: Sancta Maria cantat et vertit se ad occidentem
app.rdg: St. Mary sings and turns to the west:

app.lem: We helpet klagen myn grote leyt?
app.rdg: Who will help lament my great pain?

app.lem: Myn yamer de ys worden breyt.
app.rdg: My sorrow has become immense.

app.lem: Wo kan ik arme dat nu dragen,
app.rdg: How can I, poor me, now bear that

app.lem: Went yk in alle mynen dagen
app.rdg: when, in all of my days,

app.lem: Ny vornam sulke swere!
app.rdg: I have never experienced such a burden!

app.lem: Horen noch seen yk enkan;
app.rdg: I can neither hear nor see:

app.lem: So grot leyt ny wyf gewan,
app.rdg: such great suffering no woman has ever endured

app.lem: So yk arme nu dulde,
app.rdg: as I - poor me - now do,

app.lem: Went he steruet ane schulde;
app.rdg: since he dies without guilt:

app.lem: Dat komet van syner lere.
app.rdg: that results from his teaching.

app.lem: Hic Maria virgo inspicit filium et eleuat manus ita cantans:
app.rdg: Here the Virgin Mary looks at her son and raises her hands, singing thus:

app.lem: Trut sone myn,
app.rdg: My beloved son,

app.lem: De moder dyn
app.rdg: your mother

app.lem: An desser stunt
app.rdg: at this hour

app.lem: Vt herten grunt
app.rdg: from the bottom of her heart

app.lem: (Hic subtrahit manus.)
app.rdg: (She lowers her hands.)

app.lem: Dy byddet ynnichliken:
app.rdg: prays fervently:

app.lem: Giff my dynen dot
app.rdg: Grant me death

app.lem: In desser not!
app.rdg: in my peril!

app.lem: (Hic tangit pectus.)
app.rdg: (She strikes her chest.)

app.lem: Myn herte, brich,
app.rdg: Break my heart,

app.lem: Went ik see dich
app.rdg: for I see you

app.lem: Hangen so yamerlyken!
app.rdg: hanging so wretchedly!

app.lem: Hertenkynt, sprych,
app.rdg: Child of my heart, speak,

app.lem: Myn not ys so bytterlich!
app.rdg: my sorrow is so bitter!

app.lem: Hic Johannes capit gladium ambabus manibus, cum eo tangens virginis pectus genebus flexis. Et Maria cantat vlterius
app.rdg: Here John grasps the sword with both hands and with it touches the chest of the kneeling Virgin. Mary continues, singing:

app.lem: Trut sone wert,
app.rdg: Beloved worthy son,

app.lem: My geyt eyn swert
app.rdg: a sword of misery

app.lem: Van yamer dorch myn herte!
app.rdg: pierces my heart!

app.lem: (Hic vertit se ad occidentem et tangit pectus)
app.rdg: (Here she raises her eyes to her son.)

app.lem: Do vp dyne ogen, see my an,
app.rdg: Raise your eyes, look at me,

app.lem: Lose myner sorgen bant!
app.rdg: release the binds of my suffering!

app.lem: Trut sone, kynt,
app.rdg: Beloved son, child,

app.lem: Blodich dyne lede synt,
app.rdg: your limbs are bloody,

app.lem: Dat gift my grote smerte!
app.rdg: that causes me great pain.

app.lem: (Hic vertit se ad occidentum et tangit pectus.)
app.rdg: (Here she turns her head and beats her breast.)

app.lem: Brich, herte myn, brich,
app.rdg: Break my heart, break,

app.lem: Went yk hijr sta so bytterlich!
app.rdg: since I stand her so wretchedly!

app.lem: So enmach nemant trosten mych,
app.rdg: Nothing may console me

app.lem: Men de dot alleyne.
app.rdg: but death alone

app.lem: Ik bydde dy, dot,
app.rdg: I beg you, death,

app.lem: Kum, lose my vth desser not!
app.rdg: come, release me from this grief!

app.lem: My ys worden myn herte dot,
app.rdg: My heart has died,

app.lem: Ik enmach nicht mer weynen.
app.rdg: I cannot cry anymore.

app.lem: Eya valsche yodenkynt,
app.rdg: Alas, duplicitous Jew-children,

app.lem: (Hic vertit se ad aquilonem.)
app.rdg: (Here she turns to the north.)

app.lem: Wo synt gy myt synnen blynt,
app.rdg: How could you be so senseless

app.lem: Dat gy myn trut leue kynt
app.rdg: as to destroy my dear beloved,

app.lem: Aldus ane schult vorderuen!
app.rdg: innocent child thus!

app.lem: Wat han ik arme ju gedan,
app.rdg: What have I, so wretched, done to you,

app.lem: Dat gy myn leuent lan
app.rdg: that you let my life continue

app.lem: In so groter swere stan?
app.rdg: in such great misery?

app.lem: Yk wunsche myt em to steruen.
app.rdg: I wish to die with him.

app.lem: Hic Maria Magdalena et mater Johannis cantant secundo simul sicut prius canticum "O quam tristis et afflicta" s. et mater Johannis dicit ricmum "Ach ach, wo sere" vt prius
app.rdg: Here Mary Magdalene and the mother of John sing together for the second time the earlier song “How sad and afflicted”. The mother of John says the rhyme “Alas, alas how greatly”

app.lem: Post hoc statim beata virgo Maria, si potest hoc commodose fieri.
app.rdg: Immediately after this, the Blessed Virgin Mary, if it can be done conveniently,

app.lem: incipit secundo cum omni deuocione canticum "We helpet klagen myn grot leyt? Myn yamer de ys worden breyt" vt prius.
app.rdg: begins for the second time with great devotion “Who will help to lament my great pain? My sorrow has become so immense" as before

app.lem: Et cantat ex integro cum omnibus gestibus sicut prius.
app.rdg: and she sings with all her heart with all the gestures just as before.

app.lem: Sancta Maria quando finiat canticum istud secundo dicit ricmum
app.rdg: When Saint Mary finishes this song for the second time, she says this rhyme:

app.lem: Eya schone bouen alle schone
app.rdg: Alas, beauty above all beauty,

app.lem: Eya herteleue sone,
app.rdg: alas, son, dear to my heart,

app.lem: Wor ys dyne schone hengevaren?
app.rdg: where has your beauty disappeared to?

app.lem: Du werest de allerschoneste gebaren,
app.rdg: You were the most beautiful child

app.lem: De gy van moderlyue gebaren wart,
app.rdg: ever born of a mother's womb,

app.lem: Also wunnychlyck vnde tzart!
app.rdg: so delightful and tender!

app.lem: Dy weren dyne wanghen,
app.rdg: Your cheeks were

app.lem: Oft se myt rosen weren behanghen;
app.rdg: as if they were garlanded with roses,

app.lem: Dyn antlat scheen also de sunne,
app.rdg: your face shone like the sun,

app.lem: Dyn ogenblyk was also eyn vrolyk wunne.
app.rdg: your gaze was joyful bliss.

app.lem: >O leue sone Jhesu Crist,
app.rdg: Oh, beloved son Jesus Christ,

app.lem: Wo sere du nu gewundet byst!
app.rdg: how terribly you are wounded now!

app.lem: Dy synt dyne lede van blode rot,
app.rdg: Your limbs are red with blood

app.lem: Wentu an deme crutze lydest grote not.
app.rdg: since you are suffering great anguish on the cross.

app.lem: Eya, du valsche yoden deyt,
app.rdg: Oh you false deed of the Jews,

app.lem: Du werest dar sere to bereyt
app.rdg: which was well built

app.lem: Dattu myn leue kynt mochtest bevlecken!
app.rdg: to stain my beloved child!

app.lem: Ik wyl dat wedder bedecken:
app.rdg: I want to cover him again:

app.lem: Id schal nicht lengher naket stan,
app.rdg: He shall not remain naked any longer,

app.lem: Mynen do&esup;k wyl yk em vmme sla&esup;n,
app.rdg: wrap my shawl around around him.

app.lem: Wente yk arme moder Marie
app.rdg: and I, poor mother Mary,

app.lem: Eynen anderen doek wedder lye.
app.rdg: will borrow another shawl later.

app.lem: Sancta Maria accipit hic pannum de serico album, cum quo tegit lumbos crucifixi, quem iuuenis quidam tenet cum galdio Symeonis et statim subdit.
app.rdg: Saint Mary takes a shawl of white silk and with it covers the loins of the Crucified, the young man takes it with the sword of Simeon and immediately pulls it down again.

app.lem: Leuen kyndere, my ys grot not, day yk weyne.
app.rdg: Dear children, my suffering is so great that I cry!

app.lem: O Maria Magdalene,
app.rdg: Oh Mary Magdalene,

app.lem: O wat lydet nu dat leue kynd myn
app.rdg: Oh how my dear child is now suffering,

app.lem: Vnde ok de werde truten meyster dyn!
app.rdg: and also your beloved and worthy master.

app.lem: Maria Magdalena respondet
app.rdg: Mary Magdalene replies:

app.lem: Maria, aller junckfrowen eyn ere,
app.rdg: Mary, glory of all virgins,

app.lem: Ik bekenne wol, wat myn leue truten here
app.rdg: I understand well what my dear beloved Lord suffers

app.lem: Nu lydet vor vns allen;
app.rdg: now before us all;

app.lem: Ik mot van ruwen nedder vallen
app.rdg: I cannot help but fall to the ground in pain

app.lem: Vnde beweynen syne grot herteleyt.
app.rdg: and lament his great and heartfelt sorrow.

app.lem: O, wo he nu an deme crutze steyt!
app.rdg: Oh, how he now hangs on the cross!

app.lem: (Eleuat oculus)
app.rdg: (she raises her eyes)

app.lem: Eya Maria, neen mynslik herte
app.rdg: Oh Mary, no human heart

app.lem: Kan begrypen syn lydent vnde grote smerte!
app.rdg: can understand his suffering and great pain!

app.lem: O du valsche yodendeyt,
app.rdg: Oh, you false deed of the Jews,

app.lem: Du makest, dat yk mot syngen eyn klagheleyt!
app.rdg: it is your fault, that I must sing a lament!

app.lem: Maria plangit in medio circulo (Maria scilicet Magdalena)cantando vt sequitur
app.rdg: Mary, that is to say, Mary Magdalene, mourns with song in the middle of the stage and continues:

app.lem: Maria, moder, reyne schryn,
app.rdg: Mary, mother, shrine of purity,

app.lem: Dyn klagent wundet sere myn,
app.rdg: your lamenting wounds me sorely,

app.lem: Darto de pyn
app.rdg: as does the pain

app.lem: Des leuen truten heren myn!
app.rdg: of my dear beloved Lord!

app.lem: Here, wo grot ys nu dyn not!
app.rdg: Lord, how great your misery is now!

app.lem: Beweynen mot yk dynen dot.
app.rdg: I must mourn your death.

app.lem: Der gnaden sot
app.rdg: The fountain of grace

app.lem: Lyt den starken, swaren stot.
app.rdg: is dealt a strong and heavy blow.

app.lem: Ik laue dy, leue here,
app.rdg: I praise you greatly, dear Lord,

app.lem: An mynem herten sere
app.rdg: in my heart,

app.lem: Nu vnde jummermere;
app.rdg: now and forever more.

app.lem: Wo gud was dyne lere!
app.rdg: How great were your teachings!

app.lem: Des lyde yk grote swere,
app.rdg: For this I endure great anguish,

app.lem: Wor yk my henne kere,
app.rdg: wherever I turn,

app.lem: O koningk aller eren!
app.rdg: o king of honour.

app.lem: Maria Magdalena dicit
app.rdg: Mary Magdalene says:

app.lem: O du arme yodenkynt,
app.rdg: Oh you poor Jew child,

app.lem: Wo sere bystu nu vorblynt,
app.rdg: how blind you are now,

app.lem: Dattu mynem leuen truten heren

app.rdg: that you bound and captured

app.lem: Myt so groten vneren
app.rdg: with such great dishonour

app.lem: Ghebunden hefst vnde ghevanghen,

app.rdg: my dear beloved Lord

app.lem: Dartho in dat crutze ghehanghen!
app.rdg: and hung him on the Cross!

app.lem: O Maria, syn lydent heft vnse herte do&esup;rgesteken,
app.rdg: Oh Mary, his suffering has pierced our hearts,

app.lem: Also dat wij alle nicht vele mer konen spreken!
app.rdg: so that all of us can hardly speak anymore!

app.lem: Alle gij leuen vrunde, de gij hijr nu vmme sta&esup;n,
app.rdg: All you dear friends, who now are gathered here,

app.lem: Latet juw vnses heren lydent to herten ga&esup;n!
app.rdg: let the suffering of our Lord enter your hearts.

app.lem: Wylle gij na dessem leuende myt vrowden syn,
app.rdg: If you want to be joyful after this life,

app.lem: So danket em vor desse grote sware pyn!
app.rdg: then be thankful to him for this great and heavy pain!

app.lem: Sancta Maria planctum istum cantat bis et eleuat brachia et plangit cum manibus et hoc quando pausat et tacet.
app.rdg: St. Mary sings the following lament twice and raises her arms and mourns with her hands and then stops speaking and is silent:

app.lem: Owy, owe, wat lydet nu myn herte?
app.rdg: Alas, alas, what is my heart now suffering?

app.lem: Owy, owe, dat lydet grote smerte!
app.rdg: Alas, alas, it suffers great pain!

app.lem: Owy, owe, myr ys rechte, so en swert
app.rdg: Alas, alas, I feel as if a sword,

app.lem: (Hic expandit manus.)
app.rdg: (Here she extends her hands.)

app.lem: Dorch myne zele vnde ok dorch myn herte vert!
app.rdg: were piercing my soul and my heart!

app.lem: O, owe, dat ys my nu beschert!
app.rdg: Oh woe, that this has befallen me!

app.lem: O, owe, schach my ny so leyde!
app.rdg: Oh woe, nothing so painful ever happened to me!

app.lem: Virgo Maria dicit vlterius ad populum:
app.rdg: The Virgin Mary speaks further to the audience:

app.lem: Nu schowet, gij salygen lude,
app.rdg: Now behold, you blessed people,

app.lem: Desse groten martere hude!
app.rdg: the great torment happening today!

app.lem: Van yamer vnde van smerte

app.rdg: My heart has been cut into pieces

app.lem: Dorchghesneden ys myn herte.

app.rdg: by sorrow and by pain.

app.lem: Hic tangit cor eius cum gladio dicens sic
app.rdg: Here she touches his heart with the sword, saying:

app.lem: Schowet, wo Symeonis grymmige douendige swert
app.rdg: Behold how the grim and gruesome sword of Simeon

app.lem: Dorch myne sele vnde ok dorch myn herte vert!
app.rdg: pierces my soul and pierces my heart!

app.lem: Gy saligen vrowen vnde man,
app.rdg: You blessed women and men,

app.lem: Latet juw dat seer to herten gan
app.rdg: let this deeply enter your hearts

app.lem: Vnde byddet den ryken got,
app.rdg: and ask mighty God

app.lem: Dat he juw behode vor alsodane not,
app.rdg: to protect you from this peril

app.lem: Dat gij an juwen kynden

app.rdg: with your own children!

app.lem: Nummer alsulken yamer vynden!

app.rdg: so that you never know such pain

app.lem: Mater Johannis ewangeliste cantat post hoc
app.rdg: The mother of John the Evangelist then sings:

app.lem: Ach, wo sere
app.rdg: Oh, how much

app.lem: Lydestu, here,
app.rdg: you suffer, Lord,

app.lem: Grote pyne
app.rdg: great pain

app.lem: Vmme de dynen,
app.rdg: for your people,

app.lem: Borne der barmeherticheyt!
app.rdg: fountain of charity!

app.lem: Ik wyl lauen
app.rdg: I want to praise

app.lem: Allen bauen

app.rdg: above all,

app.lem: Dyne gnade

app.rdg: your grace

app.lem: Vro vnde spade
app.rdg: morning and night,

app.lem: Alle tyt myt ynnicheyt.
app.rdg: all the time with devotion.

app.lem: Et dicit vlterius
app.rdg: And she continues to speak:

app.lem: Jhesu Criste, dyn grote herteleyt
app.rdg: Jesus Christ, your great and heartfelt suffering,

app.lem: Vnde Marien, de so drouich hijr vor vns steyt,
app.rdg: and Mary, who stands so bereft before us,

app.lem: Maket mennighem syne oghen rot.
app.rdg: make many eyes red with tears.

app.lem: Help vns, leue here, vth aller not!
app.rdg: Deliver us, Lord, from all peril!

app.lem: Troste myne leuen susteren Marien
app.rdg: Comfort my dear sister Mary

app.lem: Vnde ok, de nu vmme dy weynen vnde scrygen.
app.rdg: and also those who are crying and wailing for your sake.

app.lem: Hic vertit se ad populum beata virgo Maria
app.rdg: Now the Blessed Virgin Mary turns to the audience:

app.lem: Groter klage ys myr not;
app.rdg: I must lament greatly:

app.lem: Owe, leghe yk vor en dot!
app.rdg: If only I could die in his place!

app.lem: Schypper, vader ys he myn,
app.rdg: He is my creator and my father,

app.lem: Vnde yk syn gebarerin.
app.rdg: and I gave birth to him.

app.lem: Syne wunden dot myr we;
app.rdg: His wounds cause me pain;

app.lem: Myner klage ys noch mer,
app.rdg: my lament is even greater,

app.lem: Dattu herteleue trut
app.rdg: because you, love of my heart,

app.lem: Wedder my nicht machst werden lut!
app.rdg: cannot speak a word to me!

app.lem: (Vertit se ad filium.)
app.rdg: (She turns to her son.)

app.lem: Hertenkynt, nu troste mych,
app.rdg: Child of my heart, now console me,

app.lem: See my nu and vnde sprich,
app.rdg: look at me and speak

app.lem: Wente ik in den sweren sta
app.rdg: because I am in peril

app.lem: Vnde ok nicht weyt, wor yk gha!
app.rdg: and I also don’t know where to turn!

app.lem: Hic Maria virgo leuat oculos ad filium et dicit
app.rdg: Here the Virgin Mary raises her gaze to her son and says:

app.lem: Eya, herteleue kynt, mochtestu my doch tospreken!
app.rdg: Alas, beloved child, if only you could speak to me!

app.lem: Myn herte mot anders mydden entwey breken.
app.rdg: Otherwise my heart may break in two.

app.lem: Inspicit filium cantans
app.rdg: She looks at her son and sings:

app.lem: Spryk, leue kynt myn, an desser stund
app.rdg: Speak, o dear child, in this hour

app.lem: Vth dyner gotliken munt:
app.rdg: from your divine mouth:

app.lem: We schall myn trost werden
app.rdg: who shall be my consolation

app.lem: Hijr vppe desser erden?
app.rdg: here upon this earth?

app.lem: Et dicit
app.rdg: And she speaks:

app.lem: Eya moderlyke herte,
app.rdg: Alas motherly heart,

app.lem: Wat lydestu pyne vnde smerte!
app.rdg: how you are suffering pain and anguish!

app.lem: Ik see mynen leuen sone weynen:
app.rdg: I see my dear son cry:

app.lem: Ja were myn herte ok steynen,
app.rdg: well, even if I had a heart of stone,

app.lem: Id moste doch nu tobreken.
app.rdg: it would break now.

app.lem: Eya leue sone, kondestu spreken!
app.rdg: Alas dear son, if you could speak!

app.lem: (Inspicit filium.)
app.rdg: (she looks at her son.)

app.lem: Spryk my doch nu eyn wort to,
app.rdg: Speak but one word to me now

app.lem: Dat my jummer wol do
app.rdg: now and that will sustain me

app.lem: De wyle dat yk na dy leue!
app.rdg: however long I live after you’re gone!

app.lem: Hijr steyt Johannes, myn leue neue,
app.rdg: Here stands John, my dear nephew,

app.lem: De ys gar eyn drouich man;
app.rdg: who is in complete despair;

app.lem: O leue kynt, sprik, wat schole wij beyde angan?
app.rdg: O beloved child, speak, what shall the two of us do?

app.lem: Dominus Jhesus dicit hic ad matrem suam
app.rdg: Lord Jesus speaks to his mother:

app.lem: Vrowes name, do na myner lere:
app.rdg: Lady, follow my instruction:

app.lem: Weyne vnde scryge nicht so sere!
app.rdg: Do not weep and wail so much!

app.lem: Dyn grot weynent vnde scrygent
app.rdg: Your great weeping and wailing

app.lem: Myne bytter marter vornyget.
app.rdg: causes my bitter suffering to begin anew.

app.lem: Allent, dat an my nu wert gewraken,
app.rdg: All the punishment that has been brought upon me

app.lem: Dat hebben de propheten van my gespraken.
app.rdg: was predicted by the prophets.

app.lem: Et cantat sic
app.rdg: And he sings thus:

app.lem: Hely,
app.rdg: Father,

app.lem: Hely,
app.rdg: Father

app.lem: Lamazabathani?
app.rdg: why have you forsaken me?

app.lem: Dominus Jhesus dicit ricmum
app.rdg: Lord Jesus says in rhyme:

app.lem: Myn god, myn hemmelsche vader, see an myr!
app.rdg: My God, my heavenly father, look at me!

app.lem: Wes hestu my vorlaten hijr
app.rdg: Why have you forsaken me here

app.lem: In so bytterlyker swere,
app.rdg: in more pain,

app.lem: Meer den sandes heft dat mere?
app.rdg: than the sea has sand?

app.lem: Seet altomale an myk:
app.rdg: All of you look at me once more:

app.lem: Wart gy martere des ghelyk,
app.rdg: were you, o my pain,

app.lem: De yk vor den sunder nu lyde?
app.rdg: the fate that I must now endure for the sinners?

app.lem: My aller werlde wyde
app.rdg: My whole world

app.lem: Ys nu worden alto enghe.
app.rdg: has now become so narrow.

app.lem: Ach, myn not ys nu alto strenghe!
app.rdg: Alas my suffering is now so severe!

app.lem: Ik byn eyn worm vnde nenem mynschen gelijk,
app.rdg: I am a worm and unlike any man,

app.lem: Eyn spot der werlde bekenne yk myk.
app.rdg: I confess that I am an object of derision for all the world.

app.lem: Hemmelsche vader, my nicht vorlate,
app.rdg: Heavenly father, do not forsake me,

app.lem: Wente alle dynck sta&esup;n an dynem rate!
app.rdg: for all things happen according to your will!

app.lem: Maria virgo respondet
app.rdg: The Virgin Mary responds:

app.lem: Nu hebbe ik volaren allent, dat yk ha&esup;n,
app.rdg: Now I have lost everything that I had

app.lem: Vnde ok allent, dat yk gy gewan.
app.rdg: and also everything that I ever gained.

app.lem: My deyt not, dat yk drouich byn:
app.rdg: It hurts me that I am sad:

app.lem: O leue sone, wor schal dyne arme moder hin?
app.rdg: O dear son, where shall your poor mother turn?

app.lem: We helpet my, vnde we gift my ra&esup;d
app.rdg: Who will help me and who will give me counsel

app.lem: Van alle den luden, de hijr vmme sta&esup;t?
app.rdg: of all the people who are gathered here?

app.lem: O leue kynt, schal ik nicht myt dy steruen,
app.rdg: Oh, dear child, if I am not able to die with you,

app.lem: Men aldus yamerlyken vorderuen,
app.rdg: but must fall into bitter ruin,

app.lem: So bedenke, leue sone, myn arme elende leuent!
app.rdg: consider, dear son, my poor, miserable life!

app.lem: Myn lijf vnde myne zele hebbe yk dy ghegheuen.
app.rdg: My body and my soul I have given to you.

app.lem: Jhesus cantat et post hoc dicit ad matrem
app.rdg: Jesus sings and afterwards speaks to his mother:

app.lem: Mulier, ecce filius tuus!
app.rdg: Woman, behold your son!

app.lem: Werde magetvnde moder myn,
app.rdg: Worthy maid and mother of mine,

app.lem: Johannes schal dyn hoder syn,
app.rdg: John shall be your guardian,

app.lem: Hebbe ene tho eneme kynde
app.rdg: accept him as a child

app.lem: -- Id wyl sik nu anders nicht vynden --
app.rdg: —- there is no other way —-

app.lem: Vnde lat dyn grote weynent syn:
app.rdg: and stop your excessive weeping:

app.lem: Dyn lydent ys my also grote pyn!
app.rdg: your suffering also brings me great pain!

app.lem: Dar vmme byn yk van dy gebaren,
app.rdg: For that reason I am born of you,

app.lem: Dat myne vrunde nicht werden loren.
app.rdg: that my friends will not be lost.

app.lem: (Sancta Maria plangit semel cum manibus, et Johannes apponit gladium Symeonis)
app.rdg: (St. Mary gestures once with her hands in mourning and John picks up the sword of Simeon.)

app.lem: Owy, owe der wesselingen schicht,
app.rdg: Alas, alas, the evil deeds

app.lem: De huten schut an mych!
app.rdg: which are being done to me today by the moneylenders!

app.lem: Seed, wo dyt scharpe swerd
app.rdg: See how this sharp sword

app.lem: Dorch myne zele verd!
app.rdg: pierces my soul!

app.lem: Et dicit eleuata facie ad filium
app.rdg: And she speaks to her son with her face raised to look at him:

app.lem: Leue kynt, mynem herten ys so banghe,
app.rdg: Dear child, there is so much fear in my heart,

app.lem: Vnde dat mot waren noch so lange, --
app.rdg: and it will endure,

app.lem: Och mochte yk myt dy lyden den bytteren dot!
app.rdg: oh, if only I could suffer bitter death with you!

app.lem: Myn lydent ys nu mer wen to grot.
app.rdg: My suffering has now become too great.

app.lem: O alder leueste, yk mot nu van dy scheyden,
app.rdg: Oh, most beloved, I must now leave you;

app.lem: Sprek, leue kynt, we trostet nu vns beyden?
app.rdg: speak, dear child, who will now console us both?

app.lem: Johannes, leue o&esup;m myn,
app.rdg: John, my dear nephew,

app.lem: Ik wyl dy gerne horsam syn.
app.rdg: I will gladly obey you.

app.lem: Johannes, wij vorlesen an desser stund
app.rdg: John, I must now leave

app.lem: Jhesum Cristum, vnser hertenallerleuesten vrund.
app.rdg: Jesus Christ, the friend dearest to our hearts.

app.lem: Nota: Maria Magdalena et mater Johannis cantant vt prius planctum "O quam tristis et afflicta" sq.
app.rdg: Note: Mary Magdalene and the mother of John sing the lamentation “Oh, how sad and afflicted”, etc. as they did before.

app.lem: Mater Johannis dicit "Ach, ach wo sere" vt prius --
app.rdg: The mother of John recites “Alas, alas, how greatly” as before.

app.lem: Dominus Jhesus cantat et dicit ad Johannem
app.rdg: Lord Jesus sings and speaks to John:

app.lem: Ecce mater tua!
app.rdg: Behold your mother!

app.lem: Et dicit ad Johannem ricmum
app.rdg: And he says to John in rhymes:

app.lem: Johannes, junghere ghute,
app.rdg: John, good man,

app.lem: See nu an dyne leuen moter!
app.rdg: behold your dear mother!

app.lem: Ik mot nu van hynnen varen,
app.rdg: I must now depart from here,

app.lem: Dar vmme schaltu see wol vorwaren.
app.rdg: therefore, you shall take good care of her.

app.lem: Ik mot nu wedder keren
app.rdg: I must now return

app.lem: Tho mynem hemmelschen vader vnde heren;
app.rdg: to my heavenly father and lord.

app.lem: See schal nu wesen de moder dyn,
app.rdg: She shall now be your mother.

app.lem: Plech erer alse myn!
app.rdg: Care for her as you did for me!

app.lem: Johannes, do dorch dyne gote:
app.rdg: John, for the sake of your god,

app.lem: Nym se an dyne hode,
app.rdg: take her into your care,

app.lem: Troste se leflyken in erer not,
app.rdg: console her lovingly in her misery,

app.lem: Wan ik hebbe geleden den bytteren dot.
app.rdg: because I have suffered bitter death. Jesus is both dead and speaking as if he is alive. This is typical for medieval depictions of the passion where Jesus regularly appears in death but points to his wounds as if he were alive.

app.lem: Johannes respondet
app.rdg: John responds:

app.lem: Here vnde meyster, dat schal my ghetemen,
app.rdg: Lord and master, that is fitting for me;

app.lem: Ik wyl se gerne to my nemen
app.rdg: I’ll happily take her with me

app.lem: Vnde vor myne leuen moder vntfa&esup;n;
app.rdg: and accept her as my dear mother;

app.lem: Ik wyl se nummermer vorla&esup;n.
app.rdg: I will never leave her again.

app.lem: Gherne wyl yk se nemen an myne hute.
app.rdg: Gladly I will take her into my care.

app.lem: Wat yk er ok kan do&esup;n to gute,
app.rdg: Whatever good I can do for her,

app.lem: Dat wil ik van herten gerne don de wyle dat ik leue.
app.rdg: I will do it with an eager heart as long as I live.

app.lem: O leue here god, nu gheue
app.rdg: O beloved Lord God, now give

app.lem: Vns beyden den dot,
app.rdg: death to both of us

app.lem: Wente yd ys vns warlyken not!
app.rdg: because we are truly in peril!

app.lem: Ach leyder, de spegel wyl vns entga&esup;n,
app.rdg: O woe, the mirror is escaping us, i.e. Jesus Christ.

app.lem: Dar alle de werlt kan by besta&esup;n!
app.rdg: and through this the whole world may continue.

app.lem: We kan nu syn trurent la&esup;n,
app.rdg: Who can forget his suffering?

app.lem: O hemmelsche god, van allen luden, de hijr vmme sta&esup;n?
app.rdg: O heavenly God, who of all the people who are gathered here can stop mourning now?

app.lem: Jhesus cantat post hoc
app.rdg: Jesus then sings:

app.lem: Pater, dimitte eis!
app.rdg: Father, forgive them!

app.lem: Nu schal ok eyn ende syn
app.rdg: Now there will be an end

app.lem: Der groten, bytter marter myn.
app.rdg: to my great bitter torment.

app.lem: O hemmelsche vader, yk bydde dy,
app.rdg: O heavenly father, I bid you,

app.lem: An mynem ende twyde my:
app.rdg: grant me this in my final hour:

app.lem: Vorgiff nu ghanslyk
app.rdg: completely forgive

app.lem: Den, de my so yamerlyk
app.rdg: those who so wretchedly

app.lem: Myn leuent hebben ghenomen!
app.rdg: took my life!

app.lem: Dat ende mynes leuendes ys nu ghekomen.
app.rdg: The end of my life has now come.

app.lem: Jhesus cantat post hoc
app.rdg: Jesus then sings:

app.lem: Consummatum est.
app.rdg: It is finished.

app.lem: Aller proheten sproke synt nu vullenbracht,
app.rdg: All the prophesies about the son of man

app.lem: De van des mynschen sone gy worden bedacht.
app.rdg: that were ever conceived by the prophets have now been fulfilled.

app.lem: Dominus Jhesus clamat valida voce dicens
app.rdg: Lord Jesus cries out with a loud voice:

app.lem: In manus tuas commendo spiritum meum.
app.rdg: Into your hands I commend my spirit.

app.lem: Ik bevele an de hende dyn
app.rdg: I commend into your hands

app.lem: Mynen geyst, o hemmelsche vader myn!
app.rdg: my spirit, O my heavenly father!

app.lem: Sancta Maria audiens hoc cantat valida et lacrimabili voce prosternendo se ad terram, plangendo manibus
app.rdg: St. Mary, listening to this, sings with a strong and tearful voice, while prostrating herself on the ground and making gestures of grief with her hands:

app.lem: Owy, owe, nu ys he dot!
app.rdg: Alas, alas, now he is dead.

app.lem: Maria Magdalena statim leuat eam
app.rdg: Mary Magdalene immediately helps her up.

app.lem: Sta vp, junckfrowe Maria, vnde wende dynen mo&esup;t!
app.rdg: Stand up, Virgin Mary and take heart!

app.lem: Dynes kyndes martere schal mennighen wesen gu&esup;d.
app.rdg: The torment of your child will benefit many.

app.lem: Sancta Maria cantat secundo prosternendo se ad terram, plangendo
app.rdg: St. Mary sings, prostrating herself on the ground a second time, lamenting:

app.lem: Owy, owe, nu ys he dot!
app.rdg: Alas, alas, now he is dead!

app.lem: Mater Johannis statim leuat cam dicens
app.rdg: The Mother of John immediately helps her up, saying:

app.lem: Maria, leue suster myn,
app.rdg: Mary, my dear sister,

app.lem: Sta vp vnde lat dyngrote weynent syn!
app.rdg: stand up and stop your excessing crying!

app.lem: Dyn scrygent vnde ok dyn weynent
app.rdg: Your wailing and your lamenting

app.lem: Vntfarmen mach den harden steynen.
app.rdg: could draw pity from the hardest stones.

app.lem: Sancta Maria cantat tercio prosternendo se et plangendo manibus
app.rdg: St. Mary sings and prostrates herself and makes gestures of grief with her hands:

app.lem: Owy, owe, nu ys he dot!
app.rdg: Alas, alas, now he is dead!

app.lem: Johannes ewangelista dicit leuando eam
app.rdg: John the Evangelist says, helping her up:

app.lem: Maria, nuew moder vnde leue medder myn,
app.rdg: Mary, my new mother and dear aunt,

app.lem: Sta vp vnde lat dyn frote weynent syn!
app.rdg: get up and stop your excessive crying!

app.lem: Yd mach nu nicht anders wesen, --
app.rdg: There is no other path,

app.lem: Is he dot, he mach wol wedder genesen.
app.rdg: — if he is dead, he will surely rise again.

app.lem: Sancta Maria plangit post hoc et vertit se ad populum
app.rdg: Then St. Mary laments and turns to the audience:

app.lem: Nu vornuwet sik myn not,
app.rdg: Now my misery begins again

app.lem: Den ik yamerlyken drage
app.rdg: that I bear so bitterly

app.lem: Vnde so klegeliken klage.
app.rdg: and lament so deplorably.

app.lem: Hedde gij em dat leuent la&esup;n
app.rdg: If only you had let him live

app.lem: Vnde genomen myr dat lijff!
app.rdg: and taken my life!

app.lem: Wat schal yk vyl arme wyff?
app.rdg: what shall I, a poor woman, do?

app.lem: Ik byn syner worden anych!
app.rdg: I have lost him!

app.lem: Johannes dicit
app.rdg: John speaks:

app.lem: Maria, nuwe moder vnde leue medder myn,
app.rdg: Mary, my new mother and dear aunt,

app.lem: Och lat dyn grote weynent syn!
app.rdg: oh, stop your excessive crying!

app.lem: Id mochte anders nicht wesen:
app.rdg: It could not be any different!

app.lem: He moste steruen, scholde de werlt ghenesen.
app.rdg: He had to die for the world to be redeemed.

app.lem: Sancta Maria cantat post hoc
app.rdg: St. Mary then sings:

app.lem: Owe, weer
app.rdg: Oh, woe, who

app.lem: Heft syn speer
app.rdg: readied his lance,

app.lem: Dar to bereydet,
app.rdg: in order to part

app.lem: Dat he dich
app.rdg: you

app.lem: Vnde mych
app.rdg: and me

app.lem: So yamerlyken scheydet?
app.rdg: so wretchedly?

app.lem: Johannes dicit ad hoc, tenens gladium in manibus
app.rdg: John responds to this, holding the sword in his hands:

app.lem: O Maria, dyn lydent ys alto grot,
app.rdg: Oh, Mary, your suffering is so great

app.lem: Id maket mennigem mynschen syne oghen rot.
app.rdg: that it makes many eyes red with tears.

app.lem: Johannes cantat post sicut prius "Maria, moder vnde maget reyne."
app.rdg: Then John sings as before “Mary, mother and pure virgin”.

app.lem: Sancta Maria cantat post hoc
app.rdg: St. Mary then sings:

app.lem: Nu ys ok weynent myr beschen,
app.rdg: Now I must cry again,

app.lem: Went yk synen dot moet se&esup;n,
app.rdg: because I must watch the death of him

app.lem: Den ik ane swere ga&esup;r
app.rdg: whom I, mother and virgin,

app.lem: Moder vnde maget geba&esup;r.
app.rdg: bore without any pain.

app.lem: Jhesu Criste, leue kynt, ware mynsche vnde ware god,
app.rdg: Jesus Christ, dear child, true man and true God,

app.lem: Du bekennest, wo grot nu ys myner zelen not
app.rdg: you know how great is the anguish of my soul

app.lem: Vmme dat grote lydent dyn
app.rdg: because of your great suffering

app.lem: Vnde dat yk dyner mo&esup;t anych syn.
app.rdg: and because I had to lose you.

app.lem: Maria Magdalena deuote plangit post hoc
app.rdg: Mary Magdalene then laments piously:

app.lem: De sune de lyt,
app.rdg: The sun suffers, sun

app.lem: De steyn toryt,
app.rdg: the stones crack, stone

app.lem: Dat laken splyt, --
app.rdg: the curtain tears, —the temple curtain

app.lem: Wo we ys myk,
app.rdg: How sad I am,

app.lem: God, vmme dyk!
app.rdg: God for you!

app.lem: De yoden bekeren sik.
app.rdg: The Jews convert, they change their hearts

app.lem: De erde beuet,
app.rdg: The earth shakes,

app.lem: De doden leuet.
app.rdg: the dead live again.

app.lem: Myt herten vnde mund
app.rdg: With heart and mouth,

app.lem: An desser stund,
app.rdg: in this hour,

app.lem: O werde here,
app.rdg: my dear Lord,

app.lem: Wij dy danken nu so sere!
app.rdg: we thank you greatly!

lem.l: Jhesu Criste, Marien kynt, o ryke god,

rdg.l: Jesus Christ, child of Mary, o abundant God,

app.lem: Wat lyde wij nu vumme dynen bytteren dot!
app.rdg: how much we suffer now because of your bitter death!

app.lem: O allerleueste, troste de armen kyndere dyn,
app.rdg: O most beloved, now console your poor children,

app.lem: Sunderges Marien, de leuen truten moder dyn!
app.rdg: especially Mary, your dear beloved mother!

app.lem: Sancta Maria plangit vlterius cantans
app.rdg: St. Mary continues her lament, singing:

app.lem: Owe, dot
app.rdg: Alas, death

app.lem: Dessen not

app.rdg: you might be able to avert

app.lem: Mochtestu wol wenden,

app.rdg: his suffering

app.lem: Woldestu van dyr
app.rdg: if you would send

app.lem: Hijr to myr
Dynen baden senden!

app.rdg: here to me!

app.lem: Maria dicit
app.rdg: [St.] Mary speaks:

app.lem: Eya, eya moderlyke herte,
app.rdg: Alas, alas, motherly heart,

app.lem: Wat lydestu pyne vnde smerte
app.rdg: how you are suffering pain and sorrow

app.lem: Vmme Jhesum Cristum, den leuen sonen myn,
app.rdg: for the sake of Jesus Christ, my dear son,

app.lem: Wente yk mot nu syner anych syn!
app.rdg: because I now much be without him!

app.lem: Nota. Planctum sequentem beata virgo cantat bis, quia deuotissimus est, si fieri potest commodose.
app.rdg: Note: If it is possible, the Blessed Virgin sings the following lament twice because it is most pious.

app.lem: In isto cantico, eciam in ricmo sequenti, sanctus Johannes tenet gladium Symeonis deuotissime flexis genubus in manibus suis directe ante beatam virginem, cum quo tribus vicibus tangit pectus euis deuote.
app.rdg: During this song, and also during the following rhymes, St. John holds the sword of Simeon in his hands, kneeling most piously directly before the Blessed Virgin, and piously strikes his chest with it three times.

app.lem: Symeonis grymmige swert,
app.rdg: Grim sword of Simeon,

app.lem: (Hic tangit primo.
app.rdg: (Here he strikes himself for the first time.)

app.lem: Du byst my vnvorborghen,
app.rdg: you are revealed to me;

app.lem: Du byst my lange vorbescherd,
app.rdg: you have long been my destiny;

app.lem: Des mot ik sere sorgen.
app.rdg: I am distressed about that.

app.lem: Hic tangit cor eius cum gladio dicens sic
app.rdg: (Here he takes it [the sword] away.)

app.lem: De sunne vorlust eren schyn,
app.rdg: The sun stops shining

app.lem: Alder werld gemeyne,
app.rdg: all over the world;

app.lem: De erde beuet, dar se licht,
app.rdg: the earth shakes in its place

app.lem: Ok klouen syk de steyne.
app.rdg: and the stones break apart.

app.lem: Dot, kum, nym vns beyden,
app.rdg: Death, come, take both of us,

app.lem: Dat ik nicht eyne
app.rdg: so that I don’t

app.lem: Van em enscheyde
app.rdg: part from him, alone

app.lem: So yamerliken!
app.rdg: and in such misery.

app.lem: Syn blot my nu rodet,
app.rdg: His blood reddens me

app.lem: (Tangit secundo.)
app.rdg: (He strikes himself another time.)

app.lem: Syn dot my nu dodet,
app.rdg: his death deadens me

app.lem: Syn not my nu nodet
app.rdg: his sadness saddens me,

app.lem: Myt em ghelyke.
app.rdg: as is my fate.

app.lem: Maria dicit vlterius ad populum
